div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Savoy Hotel, Assouan.
div.p: The first danoe of the season at the Savoy Hotel, Assouan, took plaoe on New Year's Eve, and proved a hoge sooces3. About 150 guests had sat down to dinner before the danoing bagan, and a thoroughly enjoyable evening was spent.

div.head: PMIophtochos.
div.p: The Greek Philoptoohos Sooie'y has many calls on its charity this year. The society is nnder the presidency of Mrs. Bensohi, whose name is a honsebo'd word among the poor ol the Hellenio commnnity. Mrs. Benaohi is ably seconded,by her energetio seoretary, M. Merisis, who has had his hands full these last few days in distributing relief.

div.head: Egyptian Medloai Paper.
div.p: Dr. Comanoa Pasha and Dr. Veronoff intend to start a fortnightly medical newspaper entitled "La Presse Medica'e d'Egypte." There will be two editorial commitees, one in Egypt, the other in Paris, composed of Professors Bouchard, Chantemesse, Diealafoy, Enriquez, Du Castel, Potzi, Faure, Delbet, Hartman, Calmette, de Lille, and Boinet, of Marseilles.

div.head: Braemar Castle Reaohes Southampton.
div.p: The transport Braemar Castle landed upwards of 1,000 troops from Egypt and the Mediterranean at Southampton last Wednesday. They inoluded the 2nd Royal West Kent Regiment, from Malta, under the command cf Colonel Maunsell, who entrained for Dover. JfcRoogb weather was experienced in theBaygff Bisoay, and somewhat interfered with thi,Christmaa festivities on board.

div.p: The proposed series of twelve lectures on "Home Nursing and Simple First Aid" will take plaoe (by kind permission of the Counters of Cromer) at the British Agenoy on Tuesdays and Saturdays in January and February. div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive will attend prayers in the Mosque of Saida Nafissa at Cairo to morrow, and will afterwards grant several audiences at Abdeen Palaoe. His Highness will hold a reception at Abdeen Palace on Tuesday next the anniversary of his acoession. H. H. the Khedivah will also hold a reoep tion at Koobteh Palace on the same day.

div.head: DANCE AT BRITISH AGENCY.
div.p: A vjry sncoessfnl danoe was given last night at the British Agency. Lord and Lady Cromer had done all that was possible to ensure their greets a delightful evening, and a oapital floor, good masio, and the sight of numbers of beautiful toilettes made the evening pass very pleasantly.

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Dr. Suleiman Bey Hamada, delegate of the Quarantine Board, left a few days ago for the Hedjaz, where he will investigate the sanitary condition ol the Egyptian pilgrims. The Holy Carpet leaves Abbassieh to day for Suez by speoial train.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Six oases of plagne were reported during the week ending on December 31, viz, one at Alexandria, 8 in the Nag Hamadi district (Keneb), one at Keneh, and one in the Tala district (Menonfieb). Between Janaary 1 and December 31, 1906, 631 oases of plague were recorded, against 266 in 1905 and 854 in 1904. Six deaths took plaoe during the past week and four recoveries.

div.head: THE KUTTABS.
div.p: The following statistical table prepared by the Moodir of Dakahlieh, Maher Pasha, ik of interest to those who have at heart the educational development of the native population. The total number of kuttabs recently built in that province is 268 They were bnilt at a total oo81 of L.B. 81,454 ; their aggregate endowment is £46,267, and their annual revenue is L.E 2,461. The total Wakf (endowment) land is 317 feddane ; 8 feddans being bnilt over. Tho kuttabs are distributed in the following markazes BB undir:—Minieb, 70; Simbellawin, 33; Mit Ghamr, 52; Dekeri ess, 39 ; Man- sourah, 5! ; Damietta, 3. The number of kot- tabs to be bnilt shortly is 43, with a promised Wakt endowment of 57 feddaos. These schools are being respectively built at Minieh, Sama- noud (3), Simbellawein (16), Mit Ghamr (20), Dekerness (3), Damietta (1). Mi stapba Maher Pasha writes : — "A good number of these battabs were built by rich notables of this meudirieh who endowed them with Wakfed lands taken of their own best property. In many cases, however, and obiefly in villages where rioh potables lived, the villagers themselves invited and eleoted special committees who col'e ted subscriptions and ereoted kuttabs with the money thus collected. Some of the villagers even established small Wakfs from their limited property. It is hoped, however, that other notables and villagers will not fail to follow this good exam pie, so that within a short time not a single kattab will be left without endowment."

div.head:
PRESS AND MUNICIPALITY
SALVAGO PROPOSAL ADOPTED.
div.p: At yesterday's meeting of the Alexandria Municipal Commission, Mr. Salvago's proposal that the Prees be admitted to the meetings of the Commission was adopted in principle with only three dissentient votes. The question has now been submitted to the Legal Department of the Municipality in order to be considered from a legal point of view.

div.head: AN IMPORTANT FIND.
div.p: It bas not yet been decided whether Drs. Grenfell and Hunt's great find at Behnesa, of a vellum leaf, containing 45 lines of a hitherto unknown gospel, is to be published separately or will go into Drs. Grenfell and Hunt's annual volame. This was the most important find of tho whole of last year from the point of view of Christian arobteology. It describes a visit of Jesns to the Temple, and his dispute with a Pharisee there on the failore of Jesns and hia disoiples to perform the ordinary ritnal of purification. It not only describes these oeremo- nies at length bat also Bhows a much greater mastery of the Greek language than that displayed in the Synoptics, and is said to be both piotnrerqae and vigorons in its phraseology.

div.head: KHALIFA'S RELICS SOLD.
div.p: The Bale of the oolleotion of Egyptian antiquities formed by Mr. R. de RnBtaijaell was conolnded in London last week. AmoDg the objects sold were the following : Two fragments of wall-painting on stnoco showing the figores of two men netting quail made £15.5s (Sohafer) ; other fragment", £23 (Ready); the fighting "Djibba" of the célébra ted Arab leader, (Lman Digna, with appliqués of green cloth, to show desoent from Mohamed, £2 As. (Llwellyo). This and the following lots were bought directly from the Egyptians who looted them at the final battles of the Sndsn campaign. The fighting standard of Osman Digna, £8 (Stow); the oeremonial standard of Mahmond, one of the Emirs of the Khalife, £5 15*. (Capper). This was partionlary venerated by the Dervishes, who regarded it as having been handed down from the great Mohamed. It was found on the field of the final battle of the Sudan immediately in front of the body of the Khalifa. The total was £1,843 4s. 6d.

div.head: THE ABOUKIR COMPANY.
div.p: A London contemporary gives the following appreciation of the Abonkir Company : The prosperous condition of affairs in Egypt has been of considerable benefit to the Abonkir Company, which was granted a concession by the Egyptian Government nearly twenty years sgo for reclaiming, and owning in perpetuity, lands known as Lake Abonkir, near Alexandria, representing over 30,000 aores. The Ordinary shares oarry 7 per oent. cumulative preferential dividend, then the Defeired are entitled to a similar payment, after which surplus profits are divided Although the lake was drained by the end of 1888 it was not until 1897 that the ordinary shares reoeived a first dividend of 3 percent., which was also the rate for the next three years, and 6 per oent was paid for 1901. The company then did very mnoh better, and for 1902 was able to distribute no less than 55 per oent., for 1903 25 per oent, and for 1904 about 18 per cent., which oleared off arrears as well as making a distribution of 7 per cent, on the Deferred shares. A year ago 7 per cent, was paid on both olasses of shares, bat a mnoh larger balance was oarried forward. Now the directors annonnee an interim dividend for the ourrent year on both shares of 7 per oent., and for the first time a bonne of £1 ou the £1 Ordinary shares. It is interesting to note that sboold the company, after providing for the Deferred dividend, be able to pay £5 per share as bonus on the Ordinary, then the Deferred aharos will oease to be Deferred. The company baa since obtained aD interest in additional property, and ia doing so well that ahould the demand for land continue suoh a large bonus might possibly be forthcoming.

RESIGNATION OF STEWARDS.
div.p: We are informed that the stewards of the Khédivial Sporting Club, Cairo, held a meeting on Tuesday night to dismiss the rale passed at a general meeting of the olab held on Deoember 28 with reference to the method of filling any vacancies that should arise among the stewards. After a disoossion of the situation the stewards sent in their resignations to the committee.

div.head: SAVOY SMALL DANCE,
div.p: Tuesday's dance at the Savoy went with great éolat in spite of the fact that most people had danced into the early honrs of the preceding morning, and were looking forward to farther exercice on the morrow. The band of the Scottish Borderers providing the music, naturally a very fair contingent of its offioers were preewt ; and though the ball-room was never inconveniently full there were quite enough danoers to keep the ball rolling till long after midnight. There were, of coarse, the usual number of small dinner parties, Major and Mrs. Wynne, Capt. and Lady Mnriel Beckwith, M. Kodziebrodski, Mrs. SanDders, Capt. CbandoB Poll Gel), and Mr. LaDg being among those who entertained their friends. Amongst those noticed afterwards in the ballroom, or Bitting in the hall ontside, were Lady and Miss Hemming, and Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank. Mrs. Anderson's pretty daughters looked charming as usual in pretty fresh silk frooks, made with wide insertions of net, one in pale bine and the other in cream with tiny ro?ea ontlining the insertions, and a big pink sash. Mrs. Wynne was in pale pink chiffon, Miss Blythe wearing a trailing frock of vieux rose crêpe de Chine, which was very lovely though it reoeived rongh usage as it swept the floor. Miss Rees was in cream with chiné safch, and Mrs. Bnrdekios and her two daughters were all three in white, though with subtle distinctions in the matter of trimmings. Miss Hemming also wore cream and rosebuds, and Miss Ccxm's cream satin frook was relieved by hand painted bands, revers, etc. Mrs. Leveridge, in blaok velvet and laoe over white, ard Mins Leveridge, in a diamentée white frook, pat ia an appearance for a short time, bat as they had only arrived a few honrs previously and bad had a very bad journey from Alexandria, they were glad to retire early to the quietness of theik own rooms. Mrs. Nan govicb, in a handsome dress of silver tissue relieved with tarquoise bine, brought Miss .Nnngbvich, in a pretty net dress trimmed with bands of embroidered silver tissue, and with silver roses in her hair.

div.head: EXPRESS NILE STEAMERS.
div.p: On Saturday last the Express Nile Steamers Co. Bent off with a goodly company of tourists their first steamer, the sternwheeler America, which has been bnilt in Scotland and rivetted up and completed in Cairo nnder the superintendence of the company's manager of works, Mr. V. E. Shilston, M. I. N. A. The company was formed in April last, two boats were ordered before the end of the month, and in the exceedingly short time df eight months one is plying on the river and earning money, and the other will leave Cairo next week. The America is 150 feet long and 26 feet beam and has three decks laxnrionsly fitted with oabios and Baloons, one feature which promises to beoome very popular being the glass observation saloon. The vessel is lighted by eleotrioity and heated by steam and eleotrio radiators. This should greatly inorease the comfort of the passengers and ia quite a new departure in Nile toarist vessels.

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISM
div.p: DOES IT EXIST?
To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—I have for a long time past been endeavouring to disoover whether Egyptian Nationalism Las any existence except as a jonrnalistio mirage for the use of self adver rising native editors. Cqlamns and oolumns of the vernacular Moslem Press are filled with talk aboat the National Party and its controversies, but up to now the so-called movement has never passed beyond the stage of mere verbiage. If it had the slightest olaim to a corporate existence as a genuine political movement there would have been attempts made at a party organisation and the elaboration of some sort of programme. At present it is a mere fatility and is not openly countenanced by a single Egyptian of any weight or standing. Surely if the aims of Mnstapha Pasha Kamel fonnd an echo in the hearts of his compatriots, be would be able to point to support from among the innumerable crowd of Princes and Pashas, who ought to be honoured at being asked to serve on the committee of ihe Nationalist Party organisation. What could be a more noble ideal than the revocation of the racial consoiousness of tie oldest nation in the world ? The wealth of the upper oless Dative is so great that itonghtto be a very simple affair to get a oapital fond snbsoribed to pat the organisation of the party on a permanent footing. Bat ap to DOW we do not hear of any great anms having been subscribed. Sorely if the movement had any substantial anpport, considerable earns would be soon available and the subscribers wonld be only too pleased to see their names pnblioly figure on the lists of subscriptions in support of such a patriotic object as the realisation of national self dependence. But although the native newspapers have talked about the 'National Party" for a long time past, the existence of snch a party as a coherent factor in the political life of modern Egypt is as yet nnreoognisable. The fatility of the movement is best seen in the faot that Mnstapha Kamel and his friends are so entirely destitute of any gliippses of the troth of the faot that national movements solely depend on the people themselves, that he and his followers pride themselves because they think they have obtained some recognition in London from a small section of members of the Rtdioal Party. The Egyptians appear to be still destitute of the ritath of Wordsworth's lines : /That in ourselves our safety must be sought, by our own ri6ht hands ** bo wiought, A'haLwe must stand unpropped, or be laid low. The Ye birth of ancient Egypt will never be until its people possess the elements or nationhood. At the present rime they are qoite ignorant of what raoial consciousness is, and are centuries behind other races such as the Hnngarians, Irish, Finns, and Poles, who have struggled for oentoriea and are still fighting plnokily towards national self realisation. Mnstapha Pasha Kamel and every other editor of the Nationalist newspapers know well enough that it any prominent Nationalist were offered a lucrative pobition in the Government, he would accept it eagerly and beoome as zealona a enpporter of the existing state of things as is Saad Bey Z'gh'onl.—I am, Sir, Yours truly, ANGLO-EGYPTI AN. Cairo, Deoember 30.

div.head:
MUSTAPHA KAMEL'S INTERVIEW.
JOURNALISTIC AMENITIES.
div.p: "Al Watan" says : — We hardly thought it worth while to comment on the ridioolons interview with Mustapha Pasha Kamel given by the "Pall Mall Gazette," but we have noted symptoms of the return of the old mania, from which we had thought the Pasha to have been relieved by the painful operations to which we made him submit this year and the painfol lessons that almost cost him his tottering reason. We mean that Mustapha PaBha has not yet oeased to consider himself the equal of princes and kings, and to omsider himself the axis aronnd which revolve politics and politicians. British papers obvionsly only publish these absnrdities to give their readers a comio and pleasant pastime but if they in terest themselves in bis fatnities about as mnoh as we interest onrselves in the small talk of Corea, Java, or Uganda, the pnblioation of his delusions, e.g, the statement that be abandoned the Court ont of pure and simple generosity and courtesy to the Khedive, and especially their pnblioation in Egypt, doos a great deal of harm, for it may lead a few lnnatics to believe that he iB really a great maD, who ooonpies the thoughts of kings and tkeir ministers. Enough that his discourses on the "Occupation" and the "intrns" havo given ns an annaal addition of nearly £50,000 to the Budget.

div.head: MR DICEY AND KAMEL PASHA.
div.p: Mr. Dioey, in disoassing the grievances of the telegraphists in Egypt in the "Dai'y Telegraph" concludes as follows :— The question is one about which there is a great deal to be said on both sides. All I can say is that if Mnstapha Pasha Kernel comes over to London this season, as he is Baid to intend doing, in order to bring the wroDgs of his fellow-ooontrymen before the British pnblio, 1 think he may be able to make ont » primà taoie oaee for the contention of Egyptian Nationalists, that oar British officials are somewhat highly paid, are granted exoessively liberal leave of absence, that they er joy very light hoars of work when they are in Bgypt,and that their duties might be discharged as effeotnally and mote economically by natives who understand Arabia and know the conntry.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The Earl of Lanesborongh has arrived in Cairo to rejoin his regiment, the Coldstream Guards. Lady Inneeborongh will join him later.
Sir John Harrington, British Representative at the Court of the Negus Menelik, has arrived at Cairo from Abyssinia and tbeSadan, and is tow staying with Mr. Maohell at Ghez;reh.

There is a ramonr that Sir Bampfylde Faller, who recently resigned the post of Lieutenant Governor of Eastern Bengal and Assam, is expeoted to receive an important appointment in Egypt. We do not quite see tc what post tbis rumour can refer, unless a new one is to be created. Sir Bampfylde Faller served as a young man in Egypt, and hid mnoh to do with irrigation and land settlement.

H B. Mgr. Photios, the Orthodox Greek Patriarch, leaves to morrow for Cairo for the Orthodox Christmas tide, subsequently returning to Alexandria to perform the oeremonies connected with the festival of the Epiphany.

We regret to annonnee the death of Mr. Lodger Trndean, who was formerly conneoted with the management of the Alexandria Tramway Company. He was broaght out here from Canada by Mr. Graybnrn and after being three years in Egypt returned to Montreal in 1901 and was appointed superintendent of the Montreal Street Railway sy^tjm in the place of Mr. Luke Robinson. He died at Montreal three weeks ago at his home on Fonrth Ave., Maisonneuve. The deceased had bean a sufferer from Bright'sdisease,and daring the last six months was nnahle to attend to his dories. Mr. Trndean was a comparatively yoong man, only forty-six years of age, twenty-fonr of which he had spent in the employ of the oity street railway. He leaves a widow and four ohildren to m^uru his loss.

While quite a young man, Mr. Trafleau entered the employ of the Montreal Street Railway, his first position being that of conduotor at a time when the horse oars were in nse throughout the oity. His ability was quiokly reoognizsd, and after many promotions he reached the position of inspector when the electric cars were introdaofd. This position be held with oredit until Mr. Duncan MoDonald want to Paris to assume the management of the Btreet railway in that oity, taking Mr. Trudeau along with him to manage the eleo trioal system at Bordeaox.

div.p: Famine is gaining in extent and, intensity. Hanger and typhus are spreading rapidly in several provinces. FROM CAIRO TO KERAK. SALADIN'S MARCH. The frontier arrangement, now so happily concluded, between the Sultan and the Khedive, renders particularly interesting the record of the celebrated march of Saladin from Cairo to Kerak, in Syria, proceeding along the north side of theGalf of Akabs, on his road to Damasons. This event took plaoe in the 578th year of the Hegira, or 1182 A.D. ThemoBt complete record of it is preserved in the Kitah er-randhatelin of Abon Cbâma, which has been translated in the French eerie* "Reoaeil des Historiens des Croissaird*, Histoires Arabes," tôrne IV. The history of the maroh is really ai extract from the diary, or report, of Imâd ed din,seorefary to Saladin himself. Another author, Ibp el-Ahir, also describes the famous march, bntina more condensed form. It is probable that this successful passage of Saladin's troops, and that of the army of Sultan .Beibars 84 years later, who hurried from Cairo to Petrs, may have impressed the miud of Saltan Abdnl Hamid with the idea of repossessing himself of the strategic "tête da golfe," and of the rente from Egypt to Syria. The itinerary gf Saladiu'a journey has reoeutly been examined by Monsieur Clermont Gannean, who is able to explain the varioas sites mentioned by Abon Cbâms, who says as follows:

"The 5th Moharrem the Sultan set out from El Birkeh quarter of Cairo to proceed to Syria He followed by the way of Sader and Eilah by the desert." These two sites are on the northern coast of the Akaba Golf and appear here as in a parenthesis, for the earliest stage east of Cairo now appears. "He passed the first night at Bowaib," the usual halt for a Syrian caravan or Meoca pilgrims mentioned by Arabio authors as on the way towards Snez. 1 Then he made halts saooessiveiy at El Djisr, OuAli Mousa, Hatha, and Sader."

The first of these may be a site ou the Saez Canal a little north of Ismailieh, bearing that name, bat if so Sdadin turned off to the north, the nsnal track being to Ajrond, north West of Suez. So probably there was another El Djisr nearer to the Red Bea. Owadi Monsa is evidently a soribal error for O'yoûn Mouss, the springs of Moses, to tha east of the Suez Gulf. The two suooeeding rjstiug places, Hatha and Sader—one tho Wadi Aththa and the other Wadi Sadr ; or Sedonr, as in some modem mapp,—prove that the Saltan proceeded southward along the east of the Galf, after leaving the Wells of Moses. The historian then telis ns he orossed the desert in five nights of marohing, coming ont at Ai'a Akaba at the apex of the Gilf of that name. This route was a little to the soath, or lower dowa the Sinaitio penin sals, than the usual pilgrim way and so somewhat shorter ; but Saladin had to supply with water and food a large army and transport, and so reduced to the utmost the length of the desert marches At Aïla he entered Syria, and thence steered almost due north, leaving Kerak, which ha masked with a detachment, on hi* left ; ho passed Hisma, the projecting spar of the moantaios of Edom which overshadows the road from Akaba to Kerak. With the remainder of the march to Damascus we need not concern ourselves, the interest for present day Egypt lying in the fact that for an army desiring to pas* from Egypt to Damascas, or vice versa, the line of ronte along the Akaba Galf throagh the territory now permanently retained by Egypt. We hope that soon a light railway conneoting Suez with Akaba will render ea^y the journey of the Mecca pi'grims and lead to a vast com- between the Nile valley and Syria.

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE.
div.p: CARRIAGE IMPORTS-

The Journal of the British Chamber of Commerce says :— Prior to the commencement of tha onrrent year, the Castoms authorities did not keep separate statistics for carriages, the same being inoluded with the returns for boats, tngs launches, bioyoles, motorcycles, and BO forth. On the 1st January 1906 this classification was Bob divided, and we have been permitted to extoaot from the record* the following particulars relating to the principal countries importing carriages daring the ten months ending 31st Ootober last.
CARTS, WAGGONS, CARRIAGES
L.E. L.E.
England 1,873 2,946
Austria 4 8,812
Italy 61 4,291
Germany 18,300 385
Belgium 1,296 189

It may be assnmed that the figures relating to countries other than the above are not of any moment, and that the retarns quoted represent praotioally the whole of the impôrtB I daring the period in question. On this basis it will thus be seeu that the trade in European carriages is only, comparatively speaking, of | small dimensions, and that Bngland has not a large share of the same. The most common type of carriage in nse in Egypt is the pair horse Viotoria or Mi-Lord, lha shipments being made principally from Franoe, Austria and Italy. The retail pricé rans from say L E. 110 to L.E. 140, according to the upholstering and general fitting up of the oarriage. Although Franoe is to some extent assisted by the mere faot that the goods are made in that country—the name ooantiog fot something—her carriages are to a œrtain extent snperior to the English productions in point* of luxurioneness and general ohmfort. In other words, their lines are finer, their shapes mote elegant, and the fittings on a more lavish scale than the home tarn ont. Another item to which the French pay great attention is the question of the elasticity, so to speak, of the framewoik when fitted on to the springs. Tbe latter, themselves, are not so strong and rigid as the Euglish onep, and this, natnrally, is in favour of comfort. Another point to be noticed is that a rather lighter and smaller carriage is required in Egypt than at home, owing to the faot that the horses here are smaller than the English bred animal. Asa rule, the Arab or 3yriao pony only runs abont 14.2 hands. On the sntjaot of workmanship and materials employed, we think we are scarcely exaggeiating in sayiog that England is generally admitted to lead the way, though it must not be forgotten that some of the Continental houses also turn out a first class artiole. As a rale, however, the English wood has a reputa tion for being better seasoned than that used by the foreign firms, whilst, at the same time, the leather and olothwork is of stronger and more darable quality, with the result that the life of the carriage is much longer. This latter featuie.so far as the upholstering is (Sbocerned, is not altogether one to be connted npon to any great extent in favour of England, for we are rather inclined to the theory that, .owing to the rapid and strong action of the snn, tho wealthy olasses here prefer to have cheaper fittings, and to renew them more regularly than would be really necessary in the Case of the better English goods. Athoagh the greater part of the "voitures de loxe' come from abroad, a certain number are made locally. In Csiro and Alexandria there are several European coach builders who are prepared to oopy almost any style of carriage, and to turn out an artiole sufficiently "chic" to mi et the requirement* of those who do not wish to pay Continental prices. In snob instances, the wheels, axles and springs are generally imported from Europe, whilst the same remarks apply to the leather fittings. The indiarubber tyres come from England, Germany, Frauoeand America, the price here being from 5 to 9 francs (4/- to 7/) the kilogramme (2.2 lbs.)

div.head: Egyptian Cotton in the U.S.A.
div.p: MILLS OBLIGED TO USE IT.

The "New York Cothffiatciar pnblishea the following from Fill RiVeT,'Màss. The somroity of bigh-gtade Cotton is toaOhing alarming proportions, and'mills thatoOmrome the long staple art confronted with â'vÿiatibas problem frith little relief id1 sight, Aooofding to looal brokers whodeal largely in the prodnofc ot the Mississippi Delta,1 comparatively Httle ootton oaD be seenred for the consump'ion of local millp, an J for pfâotïCaTpnrposes Egyptian ootton is being used extensively,' bat it does not prodaoe the same standard of goods that the Amerioan long Btaple does. It n a known faot that weather conditiotas have largely been responsible for the meagre supply of high-grade ootton and this has been substantiated by a personal observation which has been condnoted by two well-known mill agents and a prominent ootton broker. It is claimed by the southern planter that the heavy storms have worked bavoo with ' the staple ootton, and this, ooapled with the faot that shipping aooommodationB are very bad, make a condition not easily understood by northern interests. It has been hinted at that' the soathern planter is withholding the trad state of affairs and has negotiated with foreign factors fot the purchase of a large percentage of the crop. However this may be, the simple faot remains that there is an abnormal shortage and consumers are called npon to meet - unparalleled conditions in the ootton market. Egyptian ootton landed in this oity brings about 20 oenta, bat it is olsimed that this grade does not prodaoe the same quality of yarn that the Amerioan long staple does. This annoying state of affairs does not obtain sole'y in Massachusetts, bat Rhode Island is likewise affected. There is evidence everywhere in fine goods mill towns of the need of high grade ootton. The short staple found mostly in Texas'will not serve the purpose of those mills that use long staple ootton, although it is claimed by some northern mills that ootton planters are pushing forth their damaged pro- duots, it being noticeable in a stained condition oaused by the floods. It has been stated that a portion of the crop is being withheld for speonlative purpose-», the planters having hopes to realize a prinoely sum. It is to be expected, however, that all kinds of stories will be afloat concerning the probable cause of the shortage, but it seems a faot that the floods have been instrameotal in damaging the orop to a great extent The condition in the' Yaw material market will have a tendency to harden the price of fine yarns and will necessitate a delay in the deliveries. The finer counts in yarn are gene rally in good demand and ordinarily bring a high figure on the market. If existing conditions are not relieved in a measure the mills will be.confronted with a problem that will not be easily solved, for, as it is now, the ootton market is oansing endless worry to manufacturing interests.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market.

The squeeze at the end of the year has been exceptionally severe, and Amerioan houses have freely paid as moch as 10 per cent for financing loans against the best railway fecorities. As our bankers deoline to 6 -, an ce Amerioan bills, they resorted to the expedient of sending the eeonrities to this side, and loaning on them heavily. While this sort of business is for the moment very profitable to the fiuano al houses here, it is brooming more and more o'ear that it is impossible for Lmdou to finanoe America to any large extent, and by agreement between barkers snoh business will necessarily have to be restricted, and New York left to ficanoe itself. It is beooming more and more apparent that while oheap money may be looked for next month, in the present aotive state of trade all the world over no return to the old 2 or 3 per oent. rate is to be looked for during the coming year. The rapid development ot such countries as Egypt, Mexico, Peru, Bolivia, and Argentina, all of which are calling for the neoessary resou-ces of development, and will require farther large sums of gold, and the faot that the older countries are er joying a period cf exceptional trade activity, point to the supply of money being Bhort for a considerable time. As regards Egypt, while it is recognised as nothing essentially unsound, there have been considerable demands by financiers in that country to draw upon London fiuance houses against securities deposited in the banks, which wil'.so far as they have been successful, enable Egypt to draw still further upon the stock of gold hete.

This week's Bank statement, in normal con ditions, would be entirely satisfactory, the reserve being, as it is, £18,719,223, or £1,090,032 higher than last year, but in view of the above-mentioned considerations, it is inadequate, and any fall in the Bank rate, even when money becomes cheaper at tha beginning of the New Year, as it probably will, is likely to be postponed to enable the Bank of England to make a larger soonmnlation of gold to meet the exceptional demands which will probably come forward in the spring. To legitimate traderc the position is quite satis faotory, as a 6 per cent, rate does not hamper trade, and the bat ks in the country are not charging to ganuiie traders and manufacturers the same high rates as have to be paid here by American and London speculators. Discount houses are charging 5$ % for 3 months' paper. The Stock Markets.

From the Stock Exchange point of view the present week has Dot been exaotly satisfactory. To begin with, the faot that the settlement bad been fixed to commence on Monday, thus preventing the possibility of a long week-end holiday over Christmas, was anything but appreciated in many quarters, and the vacation was further ourtailed inasmuoh as Thnrs day was pay-day. I here was of DOoeflsitÿ a fair attendance cf members on Monday, but little business for new time was done, and the House was practically empty soon after larch-time. On the re-opening of the Honse yesterday after the brief respite, markets generally were in a holiday mocH, bat in one or two departments some fairly aotive dealings took place, and throughout the nudertone was good. The money position was, in the oiroam stanoes, Regarded as satisfactory, bat the heavy rates charged for the Carry-over were naturally'à deterrent to new busiress. Contangos on Americans were especially heavy, and in some oases no less than 13 and 15 per oéut had to be paid This state of things natarally caused nnoh anxioty in this section. To day very little business is being done in the stock rinrkets, the work conneotèd with the settlement chiefly occupying Attention. The tone is generally very geod.and in'several instances prioes show appreciable improve ment. Console.

Gilt edged seonrities have net moved mnob this week. Yesterday Consols were dull, with transactions at 85$$ tor oash, bat hardened later in the day, olosing 85$$. Yesterday there was mnoh nervousness prevalent until the portion of the aooonnt left over from Monday bad been disposed of, but subsequently a hardening tendency was noticeable. div.head: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 2 janvier 1907.

Le taux de l'eaoompte libre à Londres a été enoore rédait avant-hier de 1/8 k 5 3/4 pour oent. Ls mê oe j inr, an Stock Exohange, 'e Consolidé anglais a gagné 1/8 à 86 1/8. L'Unifiée est restée invariée à 102 1/4, de même que la National Bank à 28 3/4, la Daira à 17 1/2 et la Delta Light à 12. L'Agrioole a avanoé de 1/8 à 9 7/*. A Paris, la B)nrse était fermée lnndi. A la aéanœ préoédente dn Samedi, le Crédit For.o:er avait regagoé 2 franos à 780. La Banque d'Athènes avait rétrogradé de 1 frLC à 137. loi, k la place d'on marohé ordinaire, nons avons en aujourd'hui, k la Boorse soi-disant Khédiviale dn Caire, nne séance des pins extraordinaires qui, poor n'avoir pas fait monter les cours, n'en a pas moii.a porté aux nues la réputation déj!> si éminente do Comité de l'honorable Corporation des Agents de change et spécialement celle de son illustre et joyeax président. On sait que, conformément à la décision prise par ce Comité, il devait y avoir séance ce matin de 10 henres à 12 h. 30 m , comme d'ordinaire. O-, dès 9 h. 50, nue séance "eui gcne-ris" s'est ouverte par les vociférations des re présentants des 56 Agences, dont les nns de mandaient la cessation des affaires k l'occasion des fêtes, les antres le contraire on quelque ohose d'approchant et d'aoouns on ne sait exactement quoi. Le vacarme, le tumulte et la confnsion étaient tels qu'il serait téméraire d'affirmer quoi que ce soit. Il était pourtant aisé de com prendre que la majorité des protestataires se Bonoiait médiocrement de la question easen tielle, o'est-k-dire de la question d'établir si la "séanoe" devait continuer, on b eu si l'on devait aller se promener. Toujours est-il que le président de l'honorable Corporation ne tarda pas k faire son apparition dans la oorbeille. Calme et paterne, M. Paal Oziol essaya vail laminent de tenir tête à l'orage en s'efforçant de contenter tout oe monde, y compris le Comité de la Corporation. Aussi bien, aveo son éloquence habituelle, il fit nne déclaration diplomatique appelé® k passer k la postérité. Le président proclama ni plus ni moins que le Comité venait de prendre U déoision définitive oi-après : "ceux qui voulaient travailler pon vaient travailler et oecx qui ne voulaient paR travailler étaient également libres de ne pas travailler." Il est k peine besiin de dire que cette trou vaille, digne d'un Talleyrand ou d'an Metter nioh, sinon d'an Robert Hoadin, eut pour effet de porter l'anarchie à boo comb'e, mais en même temps de la transformer rapidement enne douce hilarité géuérale. Lô résultat final fat que personne ne voulut travailler, s'il nous est permis d'employer l'expression heurease du brave président, et qu'il n'y eut pas de marché L'opinion générale, en Bsurse et an dehors, est que le Comité de l'honorab'e Corporation a complètement perdu la tramontane. Pour notre part, nous protestons énergiquement contr^ oette manière de voir, tout au moins en ce qui conoerne notre sieur H. de Vries (toujours membre de ce comité jusqu'à décision de justice) qui n'a pas l'air d'avoir perda quoi que ce soit.

Les requérants protestent formellement à raison de l'inexactitude des oours ootés, certains de oes ooars étant erroné* et donnant lieu k des réclamations de la part des clients. Les requérants font, en outre, les plus amples et les plas expresses réserves en ce qui conoerne 'edommages subis ou pouvant être subis nlté rieurement par eux ou par leurs olients da fait des oours erroné* affiché* au dit tableaa.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
